Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Supporting GUI-Based Text Analytics on Social Media Data by Non-Technical Users

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
A wealth of information is being created at an increasingly fast rate from social media sources such as Twitter. Many researchers need text analytics on social media data to obtain domain-specific insights, by doing various computational tasks such as keyword search, regular expression, natural language processing, and sentiment analysis. A main challenge is their lack of IT background, making it hard for them to conduct research efficiently. In addition, very often they need to use machine learning models to do deep analysis, and the data-preparation process for generating labeled instances for training models can be time consuming and labor intensive.

This project studies how to support text analytics on social media data by users who do not have a strong IT background. It develops an open-source system with the following goals: (1) modularizing common text computation as basic operators; (2) providing a graphic user interface (GUI) for users to form a workflow plan declaratively without writing code; (3) supporting text analytics as a Web-based service; and (4) supporting indexing whenever possible to improve performance. The system has been under development on Github for more than 15 months with more than 30 committers and 21 thousand lines of high-quality source code. An initial prototype is setup and used by Public Health researchers at UC Irvine to analyze Twitter data. The techniques are general-purpose, systems-oriented, and can benefit many other domains as well.

POR.DRECONTENT:
1. Project Goal

The main goal of this project is to develop the open source Texera system (https://github.com/Texera/texera) to support data analytics using GUI-based workflows. The system allows users to formulate a declarative workflow using a web-based interface to analyze and prepare data. Using predefined operators such as source scan, keyword search, entity recognition, and sentiment analysis, users can easily define their analysis tasks without programming effort. In this way, we can reduce the entry barrier to data analytics and increase productivity of data scientists.  The backend is running on a cluster to support analysis on a big amount of data. We can also allow people without a strong IT background to do data analytics.

2. Frontend Improvements:

Many advanced features have been developed in the frontend, including:

  • Significant improvement on the user interface

  • Support preview minimap

  • Support zoom in, zoom out, and panning operations

  • Schema propagation: whenever a new operator or edge is added to the workflow, we can propagate schema information from the source operators to downstream operators

  • Auto complete for different fields of an operator

  • Allow users to drag and drop a file to upload data

  • Show the latest statistics of an operator during the execution of a workflow

3. Backend results:

  • Studied various frameworks including Storm, Spark, Actor Model etc to choose from and finally chose Actor Model

  • Got a better understanding of the actor model

  • Developed an engine using actor model: Akka, Orleans

  • Ran scale tests on cloud frameworks

  • Learnt design decisions that contribute to scalability

  • Learnt the intricacies of working with distributed systems

  • Developing a debuggable parallel runtime engine called Amber for Texera.

We developed a backend engine called Amber to support debugging during the execution of a workflow task.  After starting the execution, the user can pause the job at will, investigate the states of the cluster, modify the job, and resume the computation.  She can also set conditional breakpoints to pause the execution when certain conditions are satisfied. In this way, the user can gain a much better understanding of the run-time behavior of the execution and more easily identify issues in the job or data.  

Amber is based on the actor model, a distributed computing paradigm that provides concurrent units of computation using actors.  We have implemented Amber on top of two actor model systems, namely Akka and Orleans. Our experiments show its high performance and usability of interactive debugging on computing clusters.

4. Impact:

  • Prof. Suellen Hopfer in Public Health (UCI) is using Texera to analyze social media tweets to study various topics such as climate change and HPV vaccine. 

  • Prof. Wei Wang from UCLA is collaborating with us to use Texera to make their developed machine learning models easily usable as operators in workflows.

  • Professor Joshua Lawrence, Department of Education, University of Oslo, is collaborating with our team to use Texera to conduct text analytics on academic texts. 

  • Prof. Ju Fan at Renmin University, China is currently using Texera in his course “Computational Communication.” The purpose is for students in the School of Journalism, who do not have a strong IT background, to conduct analytics on social media data using a GUI interface provided by Texera.

  • Lin Zhang from National Natural Science Foundation of China is using Texera to analyze researchers’ discussions on social media platforms. She also uses Texera to analyze the past publication records to study the trending topics in different natural science disciplines.

5. Publications:

  • “Amber: A Debuggable Dataflow System Based on the Actor Model”, Avinash Kumar, Zuozhi Wang, Shengquan Ni, and Chen Li, submitted to PVLDB 2020, under revision.

  • “Twitter Climate Change Dialogue during the 2016 U.S. Presidential Election: Too little of health, local, and elected official frames that engage the public to build support for climate policy”, Journal of Environmental Communication, Suellen Hopfer, Miryha Runnerstrom, Samantha Garcia, Shahir Fouad Masri, Jimmy Loc Hua, Thomas Han, Chen Li, Zuozhi Wang,Taewoo Kim, under review.

  • "Use of Twitter data to improve Zika virus surveillance in the United States during the 2016 epidemic", Shahir Masri, Jianfeng Jia, Chen Li, Guofa Zhou, Ming-chieh Lee, Yan Guiyun, Jun Wu, BMC Public Health, Volume 19, Article number: 761 (2019)

6. Talks:

  • 7/19/2019, Talk at Alibaba, Seattle, "Amber: A Debuggable Dataflow System Based on the Actor Model"

  • 7/30/2019, Talk at Fudan University, Shanghai, China, "Amber: A Debuggable Dataflow System Based on the Actor Model"

  • 9/17/2019, Talk at Workday, San Mateo, CA, "Amber: A Debuggable Dataflow System Based on the Actor Model"

  • 9/18/2019, Talk at Megagon, Mountain View, CA, "Amber: A Debuggable Dataflow System Based on the Actor Model"

  • 9/19/2019, Talk at WeWork, Palo Alto, CA, "Amber: A Debuggable Dataflow System Based on the Actor Model"
